title: 1929 Mercedes-Benz 450 SL

description: 1929 Mercedes Roadster/Convertible. One Gorgeous Street Car and a testament to how cars used to be. Though it isn't an original Mercedes, this car is built to replicate the original style of one, giving you a truly amazing driving experience. The frame and engine are from a Ford Pinto. The engine was professionally and has 3300 kilometers on it. The Ford Pinto frame and engine were used in kits across the world for the ease of fitment, drivability, and of course, a descent amount of power for such a light car. The transmission is an automatic which is definitely a change from the original which makes this car easy to drive for almost anyone. This car was designed to be a smooth street car, and something you can take up on the highway to feel the wind through your hair and the jealous stares from everyone else. The interior is very basic, setup as designed in 1929, with leather seats for two. The dashboard is designed to be simple only having features you need for a drive but with the added feature of a radio. The exterior is beige with burgandy fenders and pin striping which makes a statement of your status in the world in the 1920's. Drop the top on this Mercedes and enjoy the sunshine in this smooth styling, and beautifully crafted lines of a classic.  This car would be a hit at any car show or just to cruise on a Friday night or Sunday afternoon.
title: 1929 Mercedes-Benz Roadster

description: For Sale at Cityview Classic Cars, a beautiful Mercedes-Benz 300 Adenauer. Technologically advanced, the 300 was regarded as a "driver's" car, sharing numerous design innovations and mechanical components with the iconic Mercedes-Benz 300 SL "Gullwing", including engine, suspension, and chassis. This beautiful 1952 Mercedes-Benz 300 sports and older restoration that has been beautifully maintained. Inline 6 cylinder engine with a 4-speed manual column shift transmission. Very nice interior with wood appointments and always garage kept. Original Mercedes hubcaps have been professionally restored.

description: REDUCED AGAIN ! Although it's NOT titled as a Mercedes-Benz, this neat little Gazelle is QUIET a bit more affordable and probably ALMOST as much fun to drive.  Where some were famously constructed from kits where they were a pretty successful way for the enterprising hobbyist to give himself something to do on weekends, THIS I S OBVIOUSLY NOT ONE OF THOSE.  One of the better looking and better-proportioned replicas of the period.   This one, now on consignment, for sale by owner and shown by appointment only, may have been built by one of the companies that were custom building them for clients because it is verry well done and the details are perfect.  Titled a 1990 - probably the year it was built - the power train is ford all the way.  And it's still a blast to drive!   Runs and drives more like a Mustang II from the 80's or a Pinto from the 70's - those four banger motors are revisited here  - brakes are drum - and the trans is automatic.   The owner, well over six foot, said;   ''inherrited it in some fashion, had my fun and need the garage space - oh and pump the brakes twice''.  If your looking for a Stand-Out-Parade-Car - OR A CRUISER ON THE BEACH - DROP THE TOP - I BET IT'LL GET MORE ATTENTION THAN  YOUR PICKUP TRUCK OR MOTHERS 1990 CORVETTE !  CALL 281-881-5239 NO REASONABLE OFFER REFUSED.
title: 1928 Mercedes-Benz GAZELL REPLICA

description: We know why you're looking at this roadster.  There's just something cool about these reproduction Mercedes-Benz Gazelle cars when everything is done right.  It has the classy red/black combo, beautifully built body, and manual transmission to take control on the backroads.  All of this makes for an attractive droptop at an irresistible price.

A pre-WWII appearance with much more modern reliability, that's what this one really offers.  You're not out to fool concours judges into thinking this is a real Mercedes.  Instead, this is the convertible for those who like getting that appreciative nod in traffic from others that have the same desire for nostalgia that you do.  This Gazelle has the great classic touches from the chrome on the headlights, to the leather strap on the hood.  These bodies always look great in red, and the black fenders even have a nice white pinstripe that continues on the main color, too.  Because this is designed for genuine European sophistication, there is the period-correct tall Mercedes-style grille in front and wire wheel covers to brighten up all four corners.

Open the low-cut sports doors, and you'll see a timelessly handsome black interior.  Slip into the bucket seat to be greeted by a wood three-spoke sports steering wheel.  In front of you is a full set of gauges set in a complete wood panel.  While this dashboard is setup to be a vintage time machine, the AM/FM/cassette stereo allows you to go for a Sunday drive while listening to the tunes you want.  And if the weather turns bad while you're out, the full convertible top will get you home.  And while the Mercedes sported a straight-six under that long hood, this tribute car has a nice carpeted trunk for decent storage.

The 1200 cc VW flat-four lives under the rear deck.  It fires up as reliably as you know VWs should, and of course, it makes that unmistakable air-cooled soundtrack.  The trusty motor and total control provided by the four-speed manual transmission moves the lightweight roadster with ease.  But the best reason for having this based on a Beetle is that maintenance is a breeze.  You have an extensive and affordable catalog of repair and performance parts available.

This one would already be a lot of fun for the money even if it wasn't out to look like a classic Mercedes.  For those who enjoy motoring at its purest, we've got your new favorite toy.  It's also titled as a 1977 Volkswagen so titling and registering it will be a breeze!  Call today!!!
title: 1929 Mercedes-Benz Gazelle

description: For sale in our Dallas/Fort Worth showroom is a gorgeous 1929 Mercedes SSk Replica. This kit car is based on a 1987 Volkswagen Beetle. The last design Ferdinand Porsche created for Mercedes Benz, the SSK is one of the most iconic vehicle designs in history. The rich cream and luscious chocolate brown perfectly accents the flowing wheel arches of this historic shape. With drivability and simplicity in mind, this kit was based upon a Beetle donor car. It utilizes the air cooled Volkswagen engine and 4 speed manual transmission with a Hurst shifter. The rear engine layout even allows this vehicle to even have a usable storage area up front, making it a perfect vehicle for a day trip under the summer sun. Inside you will find a soft leather interior and fantastic Vintage Reproduction gauges. This vehicle also includes the removable soft top should you choose to ride the open roads in the shade. This little replica will allow you to cruise in timeless style without the need to fork over the seven figures that an original will run you. To view this vehicle in greater detail including HD pictures and videos, visit www.gatewayclassiccars.com/carlist2?src=2&location=DFW. For additional information on this 1966 Ford Mustang, email us at dallas@gatewayclassiccars.com or call 817-310-9400.
title: 1929 Mercedes-Benz Gazelle

description: Representing a earlier comprehensive restoration this Mercedes W136 Chassis 170Va is a delightful vehicle to own, garnering a phenomenal amount of attention when on the road and at shows.

Iconic and historical in its design, it was manufactured in various iterations from 1936 to 1955 with successive upgrades over the years, and of course a hiatus during world war two when its factory was heavily bombed out.
Very fun to drive, and certainly a urban dweller given its smaller displacement engine and manual four speed transmission.
You may contact Luke at 413-253-4249 for further information.  Shown exclusively by appointment only.

title: 1932 Mercedes-Benz 540K

description: If you're the kind of guy who likes a vintage look but a more modern performance envelope, a car like this Gazelle replica of a 1929 Mercedes-Benz is probably a great choice. Based on rugged and reliable Ford components but with that classic long hood and swooping fenders, it has a look that definitely gets noticed.

Of course the body is fiberglass, but nobody's going to care. The Gazelles were some of the better replicas, getting the proportions right and not straying too far from the original look. The colors on this one also work rather well, as most of them you see are some combination of brown and tan, which dates from the 1970s when most of them were built. In contrast, this car's gray bodywork with burgundy fenders is classic and elegant, while adding a touch of sportiness to the low-slung roadster. The bodywork is in good shape and since it's fiberglass, dents and rust are non-issues. It does show a few signs of use, but you really have to go looking for them and the fit of the hood and doors is actually pretty impressive given the reasonable sticker price. Details like the expose exhaust pipes coming out of the hood, the big, round headlights, and the leather strap holding the hood down are all throwbacks to the original Mercedes SSK, the model on which the Gazelle was undoubtedly modeled.

The burgundy interior offers buckets seats up front, something the early Mercedes-Benz probably lacked, as well as a modest rear bench that's good for kids or parcels. Red carpets are nicely fitted, but now showing some fading, which is probably inevitable with a convertible like this. The dash and steering wheel are wood, which is a bit of a throwback to an earlier era, and the big, round vintage gauges certainly look suitably old (note that the speedo reads in KPH and the odometer runs a little fast as a result). There's an AM/FM/CD stereo system over in front of the passenger, and it looks to be recently installed; that's a feature they probably would have welcomed decades ago if it were available. For inclement weather, there's a folding black convertible top that stows pretty easily, and it comes with a full set of matching side-curtains for the worst stuff.

The powertrain is surprising because this isn't some VW Beetle-based repop, but a real road car thanks to a Ford 2.8 liter V6. Called the Cologne engine, it's a German-built engine used in vehicles like the Mercury Capri and more recently, the Bronco II and Ranger pickup. As a result, it's durable, torquey, and easy to service with great parts availability. There's a carburetor on top and it's a tight squeeze in the engine bay, but service access is decent and many of the parts look new, including the carburetor and alternator. With a recent tune-up, it starts right up and drives well, and with an automatic transmission, anyone can slide behind the wheel and enjoy the vintage experience. Underneath, it sits on a custom tube-frame chassis that incorporates a Mus
